Author: Acura#2748
Content: Hello JL777 - i got 2 Questions from a user: How does the transaction size differ from the block size? A pirate block is 4MB in size and the actual transactions are only 200kB in size? What about the rest of the 3.8MB? Is the block size of 4MB then fixed for each asset chain?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are 1 or more transactions in a block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: confused at the confusion

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
```Block #156357
Size (bytes)     31925
 Transaction 8c2fd8bf77b5e427322fe639e074efe48befea4930b8174fd423b1493e4dd8bf 
Size     253 (bytes)
 Transaction 459075ec071f3529d46919e9dcc70ee31b28feb88c97ae3df8884630e6ddda15 
Size     8445 (bytes)
 Transaction 3679172faf7f3f2934205e07cc6e4cf75c80429a5063937e8266bf5766d08cd1 
Size     5601 (bytes)
 Transaction 25180a87d90cc15c29c9f041d9e88f5d862db2d1c71e3cf500421f0197e0ae9a 
Size     1857 (bytes)
Transaction c554da3cb4cfd14bc78f5fd18a2ea7b6588cd5f2103df091533bd56533d564f8
Size     8414 (bytes)
 Transaction 85c21b77884e27d0b836d849e27ed923818d8e9ae0a9fc68451576a15fce701d 
Size     1971 (bytes)
Transaction 3af125a960640598d9f9f948f3f890721fa6a0a1d16d4589d81ec3f00a0ea401
Size     2267 (bytes)
Transaction 339be0284a40cf9ebe00f33879fd3e63c0f7c4f531b6d2c15d64d6a5b50fc4ad
Size     1629 (bytes)
253+8445+5601+1857+8414+1971+2267+1629=30437

block-txs=
31925-30437=1488```

The block overhead is less than the smallest non-cb tx in it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: max size means just that the maximum allowed size. smaller is ok too

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: think of a block as a box. this box holds up to 4MB, but it can be almost empty to

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: think of tx as cans that you put into the box,these can be up to 200kb, but they can be much smaller, typical tx is 2kb

Author: sgp#7572
Content: @jl777c does Komodo search for the chains with the greatest work, or the greatest number of blocks? I'm trying to figure out how the notary nodes' mining of blocks with low difficulty factors into this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses the standard consensus rules for the non-notarized chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the NN easy mining is only for KMD, no other chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so this seems to mean a shorter chain with more work could do small reorgs of the notary mined blocks, not giving notary mined blocks any special protections

Author: sgp#7572
Content: all right, so the chain with the most work put onto it. thanks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is notarized

Author: sgp#7572
Content: we already discussed this but just to be especially clear: suppose a node is on chain A with total work 100. It sees chain B with a more recent notarization, but the total work is only 50. It does not switch over. No issues with this, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: chain A is notarized? if so and B is in conflict, that node will stay on A

Author: sgp#7572
Content: chain A has 100 work and chain B has 50 work. both are notarized at point A shared between both chains. Chain B is also notarized at point B exclusive to chain B

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
the notarization is not messing with chain weight calcs, it is just filtering out new blocks that try to reorg a notarization, and all notarized blocks were achieved by global consensus as to the chain as of a recent height. Given those changes to the normal consensus rules, is the answer to what each node will do. 

In your example, you say both are notarized at point A, so all nodes have that notarized block. How could chain B then be the consensus block if it only hash chain work of 50? It seems chain B would not be a legal one as chain A has more weight, but if chain A is part of chain B, how can the weight of be end up at 50?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: A chain needs to be legal for there to be a consensus that it is notarized at any given height. If it is illegal, then no node would accept the notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: Only very small changes to the consensus rules were made. it is not like any random chain can be notarized and pushed onto all the nodes

Author: sgp#7572
Content: I'm not talking about the notarization process, I'm discussing a situation where one chain without a notarization has more work than the notarized chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i must have gotten confused as that is not what I read...

Author: sgp#7572
Content: there are many circumstances where this could be possible

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a chain that is not notarized cannot reorg a notarized chain

Author: sgp#7572
Content: notice how I never mentioned reorgs at all, let's put that aside for now

Author: sgp#7572
Content: suppose a node is currently on the longer chain A

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: There are 2 places in the main.cpp that implement the dPoW. Where it currently looks at checkpoints and where it tries to disconnect the tip

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the checkpoint code rejects any block that is earlier than a checkpoint

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the disconnecttip change returns an error if it is the notarized block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a node is on the longer chain A with a notarization, the above two rules would make it so it wont see blocks from chain B

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it waits for the chain to obtain consensus and then makes what is basically a 13of 64 multisig tx as what is basically a proposed notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then the nodes check to see if it is in their mainchain and updates their notarization state if it is

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: I'm looking at the gamecredits PR that added Komodo, and curious how the proof system. How does the GC chain actually get the notary proofs? Are they submitted to the GC blockchain as some special tx, or do nodes monitor some external network?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PoS chains tend to have much less issues with 51% but having an external reference solves most (all?) the objections against PoS consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: normal nodes just look for a the 13 vin 1 output notarization tx in the blocks as they come in

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we cant assume that all nodes are connected to any other chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notarization tx puts the notarization height and blockhash in the opreturn

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notarization p2p network runs a decentralized protocol and it doesnt submit the local notarization tx until the tx to the other chain is succeeded. Since the txid of the notarization is needed to be put in the local chain data, this is a prerequisite

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it would be possible for all nodes to cross check the other chain for the notarization txid, but currently we are not doing that as we cant assume a node will be running both KMD and BTC

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: As it is right now though, if you had some group of colluding nodes, they could in theory communicate in private and submit a different notarization proof to GC than they do to the notary p2p network and/or kmd/btc?

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: That was where my idea got stuck heh... that and mine didn't involve a notary system at all, it was rather just some "here's proof that this chain existed at this point in time" which is useful for preventing long (>500 block) stake attacks... but then if it's consensus, it needs some way to communicate with BTC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it would need to be validated by all nodes as exisiting on the GC mainchain, by each node

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so yes, 13 evil notaries could create notarizations that dont follow the notarization p2p protocol

Author: ğŸ„´ğŸ„°ğŸ…ğŸ„»ğŸ…‰#5039
Content: but only when they all win the lottery... I'm curious though of what effect that would have

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the only advantage I have seen is they can boost their mining ROI by orphaning competing chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a notarization that a node sees that is not in its mainchain is just ignored, so has no effect

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this problem does seem to require a set of trusted nodes to be the oracle for blockhash data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: private chains are invalidated with a notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but in an evil notary cabal scenario, what we want is notarizations to have no effect

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which they can certainly do
